unnormalised: So, someone asked about higher education admissions in India, eh? Well, it's a bit of a mad rush, especially after those Class 12 results are out. Getting into a good college, like say, St. Stephen's in Delhi or IIT Bombay, is super competitive. Everyone's aiming for that 99% mark, you know? And the cutoffs? Forget about it! Last year, some courses at Delhi University had cutoffs as high as 99.75%. Crazy, right?
normalised: So, someone asked about higher education admissions in India, eh? Well, it's a bit of a mad rush, especially after those Class twelve results are out. Getting into a good college, like say, Saint Stephen's in Delhi or I-I-T Bombay, is super competitive. Everyone's aiming for that ninety nine percent mark, you know? And the cutoffs? Forget about it! Last year, some courses at Delhi University had cutoffs as high as ninety nine point seven five percent. Crazy, right?

unnormalised: The whole process is mostly online now, thank god. You fill out application forms on the college websites, upload your documents (10th and 12th mark sheets, caste certificate if applicable, etc.), and pay the application fee. Then comes the nail-biting wait for the merit lists to be announced. Many colleges also conduct entrance exams, like CUET for central universities, JEE for engineering, and NEET for medical. So, you've gotta be prepared for those too. Some private colleges, like Manipal University, also have their own entrance tests.
normalised: The whole process is mostly online now, thank god. You fill out application forms on the college websites, upload your documents (tenth and twelfth mark sheets, caste certificate if applicable, etcetera), and pay the application fee. Then comes the nail-biting wait for the merit lists to be announced. Many colleges also conduct entrance exams, like C-U-E-T for central universities, J-E-E for engineering, and N-E-E-T for medical. So, you've gotta be prepared for those too. Some private colleges, like Manipal University, also have their own entrance tests.

unnormalised: Don't just focus on the big names. There are tons of other good colleges out there. Do your research, check the faculty, the course curriculum, and the placement records. Also, think about what you *really* want to study. Don't just follow the crowd and go for engineering or medicine if you're not interested. Maybe arts, commerce or even vocational courses are more your thing. Colleges also offer various scholarships; make sure you look into those too. For instance, the "INSPIRE Scholarship" can be quite helpful.
normalised: Don't just focus on the big names. There are tons of other good colleges out there. Do your research, check the faculty, the course curriculum, and the placement records. Also, think about what you *really* want to study. Don't just follow the crowd and go for engineering or medicine if you're not interested. Maybe arts, commerce or even vocational courses are more your thing. Colleges also offer various scholarships; make sure you look into those too. For instance, the "I-N-S-P-I-R-E Scholarship" can be quite helpful.

unnormalised: Lastly, keep an eye on the deadlines! They are usually in May/June, but confirm with the individual college websites. And remember, getting into a good college is important, but it's not the end of the world if you don't get your first choice. There are always other options, like taking a gap year and preparing again, or joining another college and transferring later. Good luck, bhai!
normalised: Lastly, keep an eye on the deadlines! They are usually in May or June, but confirm with the individual college websites. And remember, getting into a good college is important, but it's not the end of the world if you don't get your first choice. There are always other options, like taking a gap year and preparing again, or joining another college and transferring later. Good luck, bhai!
